case_name: State of Bihar v. Rani Sonabati Kumari

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 83 of 1956 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated June 30, 1954, of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 255 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 83 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment and order dated June 30, 1954, of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 255 of 1952.

facts.text: The State of Bihar is the appellant in this appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Patna under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bihar is the appellant in this appeal which companyes before us on a certificate granted by the High Court of Patna under Art. 133 1   c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: There is little controversy regarding the facts.

anchor.surface_text: There is little companytroversy regarding the facts, but they have to be set out to appreciate some of the matters debated before US.

facts.text: Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 received assent of the President on September 11, 1950, and was published in the Bihar Gazette on September 25, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950  which we shall refer to as the Act , which provided for the transference to the State of the interests of proprietors and ,tenure-holders in estates within the State, received the assent of the President on September 11, 1950, and was published in the Bihar Gazette on September 25, 1950.

facts.text: Rani Sonabati Kumari, proprietress of Ghatwali Estate of Handwa, instituted Title Suit 40 of 1950 against State of Bihar on November 20, 1950, in Subordinate Judge, Dumka.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon Rani Sonabati Kumari, the respondent, who was the proprietress of the Ghatwali Estate of Handwa situated within the State, instituted against the State of Bihar, in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Dumka, on the 20th November, 1950, Title Suit 40 of 1950,

facts.text: Suit sought declaration that the Act was ultra vires and permanent injunction restraining State from issuing notification under Act or interfering with estate.

anchor.surface_text: inter alia for a declaration that the Act was ultra vires of the Bihar Legislature and was therefore illegal, void, unconstitutional and inoperative and that the defendant had numberright to issue any numberification under the said Act or to take possession or otherwise meddle or interfere with the management of the estate in suit and for a permanent injunction

facts.text: Along with plaint, respondent filed petition for temporary injunction restraining State from issuing notification under Act and interfering with possession.

anchor.surface_text: restraining the defendant, its officers, servants, employees and agents from issuing any numberification under the provisions of the Bihar Land Reforms Act, in respect of the plaintiffs estate and also from taking possession of the said estate and from meddling or interfering in any way with the management thereof . Along with the plaint, the respondent filed a petition for a temporary injunction

facts.text: Court issued ex parte ad interim injunction and directed notice to State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: The Court issued an ex parte ad interim injunction presumably in terms of the prayer in the petition, and directed numberice of the petition to be served on the State of Bihar

facts.text: State filed counter-affidavit on December 9, 1950, opposing interim injunction.

anchor.surface_text: who filed their companynter-affidavit on December 9, 1950, opposing the grant of any interim injunction and praying that the petition be dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Petition heard on March 19, 1951; Subordinate Judge made ad interim injunction absolute.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was heard in the presence of both the parties on March 19, 1951, and the Subordinate Judge made the ad interim injunction absolute

facts.text: Order directed defendant not to issue notification for taking possession under Land Reforms Act and not to interfere with plaintiff's possession until suit disposed.

anchor.surface_text: and the order went on to add and it is ordered that the defendant shall number issue any numberification for taking over possession of the suit properties under the Land Reforms Act and shall number interfere with or disturb in any manner the plaintiffs possession over these properties under any of the provision of the aforesaid Act until this suit is finally disposed of by this Court .

facts.text: State did not prefer appeal against the order under O.43 r.1(r), so it became final.

anchor.surface_text: The order was appealable under 0. 43, r.  1   r  of the Code, but the State preferred numberappeal and so it became final.

facts.text: On May 17, 1952, State filed application to vacate injunction order citing upholding of Act's validity.

anchor.surface_text: On May 17, 1952, an application was filed by the State for vacating the order, on the ground that the validity of the Act had been upheld by this Court in another case involving the same points and that thereafter the plaintiff had numberprima facie case to sustain the injunction.

facts.text: On May 19, 1952, State issued notification under s.3(1) declaring Handwa Raj Estate vested in State, published in Bihar Gazette on May 21, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Before however this application invoking the powers of the Court under 0. 39, r. 4 of the Code came on for hearing- it was actually heard on May 30, 1952, when it reserved it for orders to be pronounced on June 2, 1952  the State of Bihar issued on May 19, 1952, a numberification under s. 3 1  of the Act declaring that the Handwa Raj Estate belonging to the respondent, had passed to and became vested in the State under the provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Notification authenticated by K. Mitra, Additional Secretary to Government.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by an authentication in these terms By order of the Governor of Bihar, K. Mitra, Additional Secretary to Government.

facts.text: Respondent moved Subordinate Judge on June 2, 1952, for action against State for contempt under O.39 r.2(3).

anchor.surface_text: On companying to know of this numberification the respondent moved the Subordinate Judge on June 2, 1952, for taking action against the defendant in the suit, for companytempt under 0. 39, r. 2 3  of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: State submitted that notification was valid under Art.31B and did not constitute contempt.

anchor.surface_text: When numberice of this petition was served on the State it submitted an answer in these terms That in obedience to the said order, the defendant begs to submit that in view of the Article 31B of the Constitution, the aforesaid Notification, dated 19-5-52, and published in Bihar Gazette, dated 21.5.52 is valid, legal and authorised and the publication of the same does, number companystitute companytempt of companyrt.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge on July 31, 1952, ordered attachment of State property to value of Rs.5,000 for breach of injunction.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge passed an order on July 31, 1952, which ran that in view of the numberification companystituting a breach of the injunction, the property of the defendant State of Bihar shall be attached to the value of Rs. 5,000.

facts.text: State appealed to Patna High Court; appeal dismissed by judgment on June 30, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: From this order the State preferred an appeal to the High Court. The appeal was, however, dismissed by the High Court by judgment rendered on June 30, 1954,

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art.133(1)(c) leading to this Supreme Court appeal.

anchor.surface_text: and by reason of a certificate granted by the learned Judges under Art. 133 1  c  the State has preferred this appeal.

facts.text: Beyond issuing notification, State nor its officers interfered with plaintiff's possession.

anchor.surface_text: It was companymon ground that beyond the issue of the numberification, neither the State, number its officers or servants had done anything by way of interfering with the possession of the plaintiff.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by AYYANGAR J. on September 20, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. September 20. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR J.-

facts.text: Notification under s.3(1) specified Handwa Raj Estate in Second Schedule as tenure-holder.

anchor.surface_text: The Handwa Raj Estate with the name of the respondent as the tenure holder was specified in the Second Schedule.

facts.text: Court holds that issuance of notification under s.3(1) breached the injunction order.

anchor.surface_text: The first is that before the numberification under s. 3 1  was issued they applied to the Court to vacate the order of injunction so that they might issue numberification, and it was during the pendency of this application that the numberification was issued-without waiting for the orders of the Court on their petition.

arguments.claim: State had no right to issue notification under the Act as it is ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: inter alia for a declaration that the Act was ultra vires of the Bihar Legislature and was therefore illegal, void, unconstitutional and inoperative and that the defendant had numberright to issue any numberification under the said Act or to take possession or otherwise meddle or interfere with the management of the estate in suit and for a permanent injunction

holdings.text: The order of the Subordinate Judge dated March 19, 1951 prohibited the State from issuing a notification under s.3(1) of the Bihar Land Reforms Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, the only notification contemplated by the provisions of the Act immediately relevant to the suit, was a notification under s. 3(1). Such a notification has the statutory effect of divesting the owner of the notified estate of his or her title to the property and of transferring it to and vesting it in the State. We, therefore, hold that this objection must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of order in light of plaint, temporary injunction petition, and Act's provisions; only relevant notification is under s.3(1) which divests title; s.4 requires no notification.

holdings.text: The injunction order was not ambiguous or reasonably capable of two interpretations, and the State did not act bona fide on an alternative interpretation.

anchor.surface_text: Stated in these terms, the contention appears unexceptionable... We are clearly of the view that the case before us does not satisfy either condition. In dealing with the first contention urged by learned Counsel, we have pointed out the true construction of the order-and in our opinion that is the only construction which it could reasonably bear.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order's plain meaning unambiguous; State's prior application to vacate injunction and counter-affidavit show understanding it prohibited notification; no denial of breach or regret expressed.

holdings.text: Proceedings under O.39 r.2(3) CPC for disobedience of injunction are enforcement mechanisms akin to execution of decree under O.21 r.32, not tort proceedings; Crown/State immunity from tort does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: Order 21, r. 32 sets out the method by which such decrees could be executed... The third point urged lacks substance and is rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: O.39 r.2(3) identical to O.21 r.32 for permanent injunction execution; Art.300 permits suits/decrees against State; prior cases obiter and distinguishable.

holdings.text: The State is bound by O.39 r.2(3) CPC expressly as 'defendant' and by necessary implication from CPC scheme for suits against Government (ss.79-82).

anchor.surface_text: the rule of construction that the Crown was not bound by a statute unless by express words or by necessary implication... We are clearly of the opinion that the entire argument should be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: CPC Part IV (ss.79-82) and Order XXVII govern suits against State; 'person' in O.39 r.2(3) includes defendant State; enforcement machinery must apply to State.

holdings.text: The notification under s.3(1) was an act of the State Government; Governor responsible under Arts.154(1) and 166.

anchor.surface_text: the terms of Art. 154(1) of the Constitution... This last point also is therefore without force and has to be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification issued in Governor's name, authenticated per Art.166(2); executive power exercised through subordinates for whom Governor responsible per Art.154(1).

holdings.text: Article 31B provides no defence to breach of an injunction order.

anchor.surface_text: The only matter here set out, viz., that the constitutional validity of the Act had been affirmed by an amendment of the Constitution, could obviously afford no defence to the breach of an injunction order and indeed this was not sought to be supported before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Validity of Act irrelevant to obligation to obey subsisting court order.

holdings.text: The State of Bihar is liable to be proceeded against under O.39 r.2(3) CPC for wilful disobedience of temporary injunction order.

anchor.surface_text: The principal point of law raised for decision in the appeal is whether a State is liable to be proceeded against under O. 39, r. 2(3) of the Code of Civil Procedure, when it wilfully disobeys an order of temporary injunction passed against it... The third point urged lacks substance and is rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects all defences; CPC binds State; enforcement not criminal/tort; cumulative holdings on interpretation, ambiguity, immunity, bindingness, attribution.

holdings.text: Every authority including Executive Government must obey court orders; disobedience subverts administration.

anchor.surface_text: It is of the essence of the rule of law that every authority within the State including the Executive Government should consider itself bound by and obey the Law... If disobedience could go unchecked, it would result in orders of Courts ceasing to have any meaning.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle of rule of law and separation of powers.

precedents.cited_proposition: liability of the Crown in tort were discussed. The question for consideration before the learned Judges was whether the suit before the Court against the Government could be legally maintainable and as to the scope and limits of the rule, respondeat superior in such actions against the State

The question for consideration before the learned Judges was whether the suit before the Court against the Government could be legally

precedents.cited_proposition: A State as such cannot be said to commit contempt. In the case of the State the allegation must be against a particular officer or officers of the State; Article 300 of the Constitution provides for proceedings by way of suit against the State and cannot be extended to contempt proceedings

precedents.citation: Director of Rationing Distribution v. Corporation of Calcutta  1

anchor.surface_text: the invocation of the rule of construction that the Crown was not bound by a statute unless by express words or by necessary implication the intention so to bind was manifested, was the next submission of learned Counsel, reliance being placed for the position, on the recent decision of this Court in Director of Rationing Distribution v. Corporation of Calcutta  1 . We shall proceed to consider the soundness of the contention

precedents.case_name: Director of Rationing and Distribution v. Corporation of Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: rule that the Crown or State is not bound by a statute unless named therein expressly or by necessary implication

precedents.citation: The Director of Rationing v. Corporation of Calcutta  1

anchor.surface_text: the rule of Construction approved by this Court in The Director of Rationing v. Corporation of Calcutta  1 . It was further pressed upon us that the construction suggested would not render injunction orders passed on the State when it was a defendant brutum fulmen, because, the State as a juristic person could act only through human agency and there would always be some officer-a natural person guilty of disobedience in every case where orders passed against a State were disobeyed.

precedents.case_name: Director of Rationing and Distribution v. Corporation of Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: rule of construction that the Crown was not bound by a statute unless by express words or by necessary implication

anchor.surface_text: As Maxwell  1  puts it The Crown is sufficiently named in a statute when an intention to include it is manifest . Cf. Moore V. SMith,  1859  28 L.J.M.C. 126. The only point remaining for consideration is as to whether the publication of the notification under s. 3(1) which was treated by the Subordinate Judge to be the disobedience, had been established to be the act of the State.

precedents.cited_proposition: The Crown is sufficiently named in a statute when an intention to include it is manifest

anchor.surface_text: As observed by the Privy Council in King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerji  1 with reference to the term executive power in Ch. 2 of Part 3 of the Government of India Act, 1935, corresponding to Part VI, Ch. II of the Constitution  the term executive is used in the broader sense as including both a decision as to action and the carrying out of the decision .

precedents.cited_proposition: the term executive power includes both a decision as to action and the carrying out of the decision

anchor.surface_text: In Emperor v. Sibnath Banerji  1 , already referred to, Lord Thankerton pointing out the distinction between delegation by virtue of statutory power therefor and the case of the exercise of the Governor's power by authorized subordinates under the terms of s. 49(1) of the Government of India Act, 1935  corresponding to Art. 154(1)  , said Sub-a. (5) of s. 2  of the Defence of India Act, 1939  provides a means of delegation in the strict sense of the word, namely, a transfer of the power or duty to the officer or authority defined in the sub. section, with a corresponding divestiture of the Governor of any responsibility in the matter, whereas under s. 49(1) of the Act of 1935, the Governor remains responsible for the action of his subordinates taken in his name.

precedents.cited_proposition: the Governor remains responsible for the action of his subordinates taken in his name
precedents.cited_holding: Governor remains responsible for the action of his subordinates taken in his name

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, the only notification contemplated by the provisions of the Act immediately relevant to the suit, was a notification under s. 3(1). Such a notification has the statutory effect of divesting the owner of the notified estate of his or her title to the property and of transferring it to and vesting it in the State. We, therefore, hold that this objection must fail.

Stated in these terms, the contention appears unexceptionable... We are clearly of the view that the case before us does not satisfy either condition. The third point urged lacks substance and is rejected.
